lines.text: Enter CELIA and ROSALIND

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Why, cousin! why, Rosalind! Cupid have mercy! not a word

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Not one to throw at a dog.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: No, thy words are too precious to be cast away upon curs throw some of them at me come, lame me with reasons.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Then there were two cousins laid up when the one should be lamed with reasons and the other mad without any.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: But is all this for your father

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: No, some of it is for my childs father. O, how full of briers is this workingday world!

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: They are but burs, cousin, thrown upon thee in holiday foolery: if we walk not in the trodden paths our very petticoats will catch them.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: I could shake them off my coat: these burs are in my heart.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Hem them away.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: I would try, if I could cry hem and have him.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Come, come, wrestle with thy affections.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: O, they take the part of a better wrestler than myself!

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: O, a good wish upon you! you will try in time, in despite of a fall. But, turning these jests out of service, let us talk in good earnest: is it possible, on such a sudden, you should fall into so strong a liking with old Sir Rowlands youngest son

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: The duke my father loved his father dearly.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Doth it therefore ensue that you should love his son dearly By this kind of chase, I should hate him, for my father hated his father dearly yet I hate not Orlando.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: No, faith, hate him not, for my sake.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Why should I not doth he not deserve well

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Let me love him for that, and do you love him because I do. Look, here comes the duke.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: With his eyes full of anger.
Enter DUKE FREDERICK, with Lords

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: Mistress, dispatch you with your safest haste And get you from our court.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Me, uncle

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: You, cousin Within these ten days if that thou best found So near our public court as twenty miles, Thou diest for it.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: I do beseech your grace, Let me the knowledge of my fault bear with me: If with myself I hold intelligence Or have acquaintance with mine own desires, If that I do not dream or be not frantic, As I do trust I am notthen, dear uncle, Never so much as in a thought unborn Did I offend your highness.

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: Thus do all traitors: If their purgation did consist in words, They are as innocent as grace itself: Let it suffice thee that I trust thee not.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Yet your mistrust cannot make me a traitor: Tell me whereon the likelihood depends.

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: Thou art thy fathers daughter theres enough.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: So was I when your highness took his dukedom So was I when your highness banishd him: Treason is not inherited, my lord Or, if we did derive it from our friends, Whats that to me my father was no traitor: Then, good my liege, mistake me not so much To think my poverty is treacherous.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Dear sovereign, hear me speak.

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: Ay, Celia we stayd her for your sake, Else had she with her father ranged along.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: I did not then entreat to have her stay It was your pleasure and your own remorse: I was too young that time to value her But now I know her: if she be a traitor, Why so am I we still have slept together, Rose at an instant, learnd, playd, eat together, And wheresoever we went, like Junos swans, Still we went coupled and inseparable.

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: She is too subtle for thee and her smoothness, Her very silence and her patience Speak to the people, and they pity her. Thou art a fool: she robs thee of thy name And thou wilt show more bright and seem more virtuous When she is gone. Then open not thy lips: Firm and irrevocable is my doom Which I have passd upon her she is banishd.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Pronounce that sentence then on me, my liege: I cannot live out of her company.

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: You are a fool. You, niece, provide yourself: If you outstay the time, upon mine honour, And in the greatness of my word, you die.
Exeunt DUKE FREDERICK and Lords

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: O my poor Rosalind, whither wilt thou go Wilt thou change fathers I will give thee mine. I charge thee, be not thou more grieved than I am.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: I have more cause.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Thou hast not, cousin Prithee be cheerful: knowst thou not, the duke Hath banishd me, his daughter

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: That he hath not.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: No, hath not Rosalind lacks then the love Which teacheth thee that thou and I am one: Shall we be sunderd shall we part, sweet girl No: let my father seek another heir. Therefore devise with me how we may fly, Whither to go and what to bear with us And do not seek to take your change upon you, To bear your griefs yourself and leave me out For, by this heaven, now at our sorrows pale, Say what thou canst, Ill go along with thee.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Why, whither shall we go

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: To seek my uncle in the forest of Arden.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Alas, what danger will it be to us, Maids as we are, to travel forth so far! Beauty provoketh thieves sooner than gold.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Ill put myself in poor and mean attire And with a kind of umber smirch my face The like do you: so shall we pass along And never stir assailants.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Were it not better, Because that I am more than common tall, That I did suit me all points like a man A gallant curtleaxe upon my thigh, A boarspear in my hand andin my heart Lie there what hidden womans fear there will Well have a swashing and a martial outside, As many other mannish cowards have That do outface it with their semblances.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: What shall I call thee when thou art a man

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Ill have no worse a name than Joves own page And therefore look you call me Ganymede. But what will you be calld

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Something that hath a reference to my state No longer Celia, but Aliena.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: But, cousin, what if we assayd to steal The clownish fool out of your fathers court Would he not be a comfort to our travel

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Hell go along oer the wide world with me Leave me alone to woo him. Lets away, And get our jewels and our wealth together, Devise the fittest time and safest way To hide us from pursuit that will be made After my flight. Now go we in content To liberty and not to banishment.
Exeunt
